While there was undoubtedly hierarchy and inequality in ancient Greek society, there was also a strong emphasis on reciprocity and shared benefit. The Dionysiac festivals, with their theatrical performances and communal feasts, served as a periodic corrective to individualistic tendencies, reminding people of their interconnectedness. In this experiment, choosing the right option reflects this emphasis on shared benefit. While getting 600 feels good, it comes at the expense of Person A getting nothing. This extreme inequality violates the spirit of communal prosperity that I value as a historian of ancient Greek culture. The right option, where both parties receive 400, embodies a more equitable distribution, aligning with the principles of reciprocity and shared benefit that were integral to ancient Greek society, especially the Dionysiac festivals. Although I personally get less, I am willing to sacrifice a small amount to promote equality.
